notes:
Serves as the baseline for comparing all other experiments. Use this run to
capture per-node RSS, latency distribution, and stage durations for reference.

Builds on rerank_upstream and gateway_postproc experiment data.
Goal: exploit lighter Node 1 responses (IDs only) to increase FAISS batching
while keeping the gateway's post-processing pipeline busy.

Serves as the baseline for comparing all other experiments. Use this run to
capture per-node RSS, latency distribution, and stage durations for reference.

Compare directly with batch_sweep_ll_2x2 to illustrate how batching knobs
impact throughput, latency, and memory. Capture p95 latency and per-node RSS
for both runs.

Use alongside the high-throughput sweep to produce a latency/throughput curve
for the report.

Optimized configuration moving Embedder to Node 0 and Reranker to Node 1.
This balances the load across all three nodes.

Use this run to capture p95/p99 latency under load and to ensure the system
remains stable. Include per-node CPU/RSS measurements and check for batching
backlog at the gateway.
Testing hypothesis: Edge Reranking reduces RPCs and payload size.

Builds on the earlier docfetch experiment that hit ~42 req/min but with lower
tail latency. These settings probe whether the topology still holds up with
heavier batching at the gateway and FAISS nodes.

Variant of node2_fetch_rerank with doc store + reranker relocated to the
gateway.
Focus on verifying whether lighter responses from Node 1 and a lean Node 2
unlock higher req/min before timeouts.

Expect smaller payloads toward Node 1 and a lean Node 2. Compare throughput
and p95 latency directly against gateway_embedder and gateway_docfetch runs.

Same as gateway_embedder but removes unused Embedder from Node 1 to save
memory.

Gateway Embedder + Retrieval/Postproc hub.
Expect Node 2 (LLM) to stay saturated while Node 1 absorbs sentiment/toxicity.
Gateway hosts embedder; retrieval handles FAISS only.

Compare end-to-end latency and Node 1 memory versus the baseline. Expect
smaller payloads sent to Node 1 and faster gateway->retrieval RPC timings.
Testing hypothesis: Stripping non-LLM tasks from Node 2 extends throughput.

Intended to push maximum throughput with only 3 nodes. Compare results to
previous retrieval_with_rerank runs to verify whether co-locating the
embedder with the gateway plus higher generation batching improves req/min
without hurting success rate.

Capture success rate, memory growth, and average CPU utilization across the
long run. Use the resulting artifacts to demonstrate operational stability.

Testing if moving Sentiment/Toxicity to Node 1 further improves throughput
by freeing up Node 2 resources for the LLM.

Testing if offloading Doc Fetch and Rerank to Node 2 helps balance memory
usage and reduces network traffic (Doc IDs vs Full Docs).

Optimized configuration moving Embedder to Node 0 and Reranker to Node 1.
Using Batch Size 4 to compare with retrieval_with_rerank.
Reranker moved to Retrieval node.

Closely related to the current top performer but with a balanced batch bump.
Run at least twice to smooth the +/-4 req/min variance in throughput.

Testing if lower batch size improves throughput for the best performing
config.

Capture stage-level metrics to confirm rerank CPU shifts from Node 2 to Node
1. Compare throughput against the baseline to decide if this composition is
worth the added Node 1 load.

Monitor FAISS search duration, Node 1 RSS, and RPC latency back to the
gateway. Useful for determining whether FAISS becomes the new bottleneck when
embeddings move upstream.
Pushing batch size to 12 with balanced load.

Expect higher latency but potentially the highest throughput. Use this run to
determine the practical maximum req/min before timeouts or memory constraints
appear.
High concurrency test to saturate the pipeline and measure max throughput.
